I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the People’s Republic of China (PRC) for the Hunan Miluo River Disaster Risk Management and 
Comprehensive Environment Improvement Project. 
 
2. 
(i)  instituting  and  applying  international  best  practices  for  flood  and  integrated  disaster  risk 
management, (ii) improving access to safe drinking water and sanitation services for urban and 
rural  residents, (iii)  promoting circular  agricultural  development  by  linking  sustainable livestock 
waste  management  and  eco-farming, 
(iv)  piloting  green  procurement  practices  and 
mainstreaming environmental education, and (v) enhancing institutional coordination capacity to 
maximize  the  project’s  impact.  The  project’s  experiences  and  practices  in  addressing  climate 
change and ecological pressures can be replicated in the rest of the Yangtze River Economic Belt 
(YREB), other parts of the PRC, and other developing member countries. The project leverages 
cofinancing from German development cooperation through KfW and counterpart financing from 
the Pingjiang County Government (PCG).1 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Extending  across  nine  provinces  and  two  specially  administered  cities,  the  YREB 
accounts for 40% of the PRC’s population, 40% of its freshwater resources, and about 45% of 
the country’s economic output. It has been earmarked as one of the three growth engines for the 
PRC’s future economic development. While having benefited from extensive growth since the late 
1980s, the YREB is now facing significant development challenges from (i) increasing pollution 
and  pressure  on  natural  resources;  (ii)  slow  transformation  to  green  development;  (iii)  limited 
integration of waterways, ports, and intermodal logistics; and (iv) weak institutional coordination 
for  strategic  planning.  In  response,  the  Government  of  the  PRC  formulated  the  YREB 
Development Plan, 2016–2030, which prioritizes ecological protection and the promotion of green 
development  as  guiding  principles  for  the  YREB’s  future  growth. 2 In  this  context,  the  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  the  government  agreed  to  adopt  a  framework  approach  that 
prioritizes  (i)  ecosystem  restoration,  environmental  protection,  and  management  of  water 
resources;  (ii)  inclusive  green  industrial  transformation;  (iii)  construction  of  an  integrated 
multimodal transport corridor; and (iv) institutional and policy reform. The project is included as 
part of the YREB framework. 
 
4. 
The Miluo River is 253 kilometers (km) long and flows east to west from its headwaters in 
northwestern  Jiangxi  Province;  193  km  through  Pingjiang  County,  Hunan  Province;  and  into 
Dongting Lake. At its confluence with Dongting Lake, the Miluo River forms an important wetland 
protection area and flood basin in the middle reaches of the Yangtze River system. The river also 
serves as the main source of drinking water for Pingjiang County. 
 
Pingjiang County is located in the northeast of Hunan Province, about 115 km northeast 
5. 
of  the  provincial  capital  of  Changsha  City,  and  covers  4,125  square  kilometers.  It  includes  24 
towns,  a  provincial  industrial  park,  and  a  national  scenic  area.  In  2019,  the  total  population  of 
Pingjiang County was 1,119,290, with an urban population of 513,400 reflecting an urbanization 

1  KfW is a German state-owned development bank formerly known as KfW Bankengruppe. 
2  Government of the PRC. 2015. Outline of the Yangtze River Economic Belt Development Plan, 2016–2030. Beijing. 

 

 

 2 

rate of 45.87%. In 2019, Pingjiang County was one of 51 poverty-stricken counties in the PRC 
and one of 20 poverty-stricken counties in Hunan Province. Each year Pingjiang County attracts 
more  than  15  million  domestic  visitors,  significantly  impacting  the  local  living  environment. 
Between 2013 and 2018, flooding and extreme weather events impacted 86 villages in Pingjiang 
County, damaging about 344 km of riverbanks and 36,150 hectares (542,250 mu) of cropland,3 
and resulting in an estimated CNY2,007 million in direct economic losses. 
 
6. 
Increasing pollution. The ecological environment of the Miluo River in Pingjiang County 
faces  many  challenges.  About  half  of  all  rural  villages  lack  household  sewage  or  wastewater 
treatment facilities. Farming practices are unsustainable, and farm waste management systems 
inadequate. These, coupled with inadequate management of solid waste, including plastic waste, 
have a significant negative impact on the rural living environment, increase public health risks, 
and contribute to the declining water quality in the Miluo River. 
 
7. 
Weak  institutional  coordination  for  integrated  water  resources  and  water-related 
disaster risk management. Like many small river sub-basins in the Yangtze River system, the 
Miluo River is subject to recurrent flooding, which causes extreme damage to the economy and 
environment.  Losses  from  floods  occur  because  of  inadequate  environmental  protection 
measures against floods, a lack of integrated water resource and disaster risk management, poor 
rural–urban  planning,  and  inadequate  coordination  with  national  and  provincial  programs  to 
manage  flood  risk.  There  is  a  particular  need  for  enhanced  institutional  coordination  among 
county bureaus to ensure clarity of roles and functions for integrated water resource management 
and information sharing to plan and respond to water-related disasters more effectively. 
 
Inadequate rural water and sanitation services. An insufficient supply of safe drinking 
8. 
water and inadequate access to basic sanitation services are key constraints on socioeconomic 
development in rural areas, especially for vulnerable groups (including women, children, the poor, 
and the elderly). Rural households are poorer than their urban neighbors, and a lack of affordable 
access to a safe water supply and sanitation impacts their health, well-being, and living conditions, 
while also negatively impacting the rural environment. In 2019 only 46% of the rural population in 
Pingjiang County had access to a tap water supply, and only 3% had access to basic sanitation 
facilities, such as flushing toilets connected to wastewater treatment facilities.4 
 
9. 
Environmentally  unsustainable  livestock  waste  management  and  agricultural 
development.  Nonpoint  source  pollution  is  having  an  increasingly  negative  impact  on  water 
quality in the region. This is because of at least two factors: (i) rapid intensification of agriculture 
over the past 4 decades in Pingjiang County, and (ii) the associated weak collaboration between 
livestock producers and farmers. Farmers could benefit from using manure waste generated by 
livestock producers to grow crops to circulate nutrients within agricultural production systems. In 
2018,  the  agriculture  sector  discharged  about  62.7%  of  chemical  oxygen  demand,  52.0%  of 
ammonia nitrogen, and 39.1% of total phosphorous into surface water bodies; with the livestock 
sector discharging 34.1% of chemical oxygen demand, 47.3% of ammonia nitrogen, and 55.2% 
of total phosphorous. This will increase further in the coming years. If not well controlled,  from 
2019 to 2026 it is expected that the chemical oxygen demand discharged into water bodies will 
increase  by  109%,  ammonia  nitrogen  by  108%,  and  total  phosphorous  by  110%,  with  crop 
production and livestock both contributing to about half of the increase (footnote 4).

 3 

10. 
Lack  of  local  community  commitment  to  environmental  protection  and  green 
procurement  practices.  While  the  Hunan  Provincial  Government  and  PCG  are  committed  to 
achieve environmentally sustainable economic development, the overall environmental literacy of 
local  communities  remains  low,  illegal  mining  and  pollution  discharge  by  small  enterprises 
continue  to  occur,  and  rapid  economic  development  and  changes  to  traditional  lifestyles  are 
accelerating  environmental  pressures. 5  The  significant  potential  for  reducing  environmental 
impacts through the “reuse, reduce, and recycle” initiative remains largely untapped, and green 
procurement  as  a  powerful  tool  for  meeting  environmental  policy  objectives  remains  largely 
unused. Public awareness-raising activities have so far overlooked the importance of cultivating 
environmental attitudes and values more holistically, thus limiting the level of participation by local 
communities in Pingjiang County. 
 
Priorities  and  targets.  The  project  will  support  the  priorities  in  the  PRC’s  National 
11. 
Strategic Plan for Rural Vitalization, 2018–2022,6 cascaded down in the PCG local context. These 
include (i) promoting rural ecological vitalization, pursuing green development, and augmenting 
efforts to deal with significant issues concerning the protection of the rural ecological environment; 
(ii)  pushing  forward  cultural  revitalization  in  rural  areas  and  strengthening  public  cultural 
awareness;  (iii)  enhancing  basic  services  in  rural  communities  and  training  professional  rural 
service personnel with a good knowledge of agriculture, rural areas, and rural people’s needs; 
and  (iv)  reducing  gaps  between  urban  and  rural  residents  by  developing  the  rural  economy, 
providing  employment  and  business  opportunities  to  farmers  and  increasing  income  from 
property, and helping farmers achieve common prosperity as an immediate target. Access to a 
safe  water  supply  and  sanitation  together  with  good hygiene  practices  will  prevent  waterborne 
diseases and help reduce the risk of epidemics like the coronavirus disease (COVID-19).7 
 
12. 
Strategic fit.  The project  will  demonstrate rural vitalization and ecological  protection  in 
Pingjiang County and contribute to the PRC’s high-quality development goals consistent with the 
Thirteenth Five-Year Plan, 2016–2020;8 upcoming Fourteenth Five-Year Plan, 2021–2025; and 
the priority areas under the provincial thirteenth five-year plans. It is also aligned with the YREB 
Development  Plan,  2016–2030  (footnote  2),  and  the  rural  vitalization  strategy  outlined  in  the 
memorandum of understanding between the National Development and Reform Commission and 
ADB.9 The  project  builds  on  ADB’s  Strategy  2030,  particularly  operational  priority  3;10 ADB’s 
country partnership strategy (CPS) for the PRC, 2016–2020;11 and the forthcoming ADB CPS for 
the PRC, 2021–2025. These strategies support the protection of global and regional public goods

and more  inclusive development  by protecting  and  restoring  ecosystems;  building  climate  and 
disaster resilience with nature-based approaches; reducing poverty and inequality by promoting 
rural vitalization; and improving institutional coordination and governance reform, while promoting 
knowledge sharing with other developing member countries.12 
 
13. 
Lessons.  Lessons  relevant  to  ADB  operations  in  the  PRC  have  informed  the  project 
design. 13  The  project  design  also  incorporates  international  best  practices  and  innovative 
approaches for natural capital investments.14 These include (i) integrated approaches to deliver 
co-benefits across sectors (i.e., water and sanitation, disaster risk management, and agriculture); 
and  (ii)  innovative  technology  (i.e.,  smart  systems  for  flood risk  management).  In  addition,  the 
project will pilot innovative green procurement practices and mainstream environmental education 
across  the  county  education  system  to  improve  the  overall  environmental  literacy  of  Pingjiang 
County  residents  through  leveraging  youth  engagement  and  targeted  outreach  activities. 
Knowledge and lessons will be disseminated through national and international fora to replicate 
and scale-up integrated approaches and innovative technologies and solutions within the PRC 
and other developing member countries. 
 
B. 
 
14. 
The project is aligned with the following impact: rural vitalization and ecological protection 
in the YREB realized.15 The project will have the following outcome: the rural living environment 
in Pingjiang County improved.16 
 
15. 
Output  1:  Water-related  disaster  risk  management  strengthened.  This  output  will 
mitigate  the  potential  impact  of  flooding  on  people’s  livelihoods  and  property,  as  well  as  the 
socioeconomic consequences of flood events. This output includes (i) the construction of 38.9 km 
of ecological embankments and/or riverbank reinforcements in 12 towns along the Miluo River in 
Pingjiang County to control flooding; (ii) establishment of riparian buffers along riverbanks using 
nature-based solutions to prevent water and soil losses; (iii) restoration and protection of Huangjin 
River  National  Wetland Park  to  enhance  biodiversity  conservation,  increase  flood  storage  and 
water quality purification capacity, and promote environmental education; and (iv) establishment 
of an integrated smart disaster risk management  and early warning system to inform disaster-
related decision-making and improve institutional coordination. 
 
16. 
Output  2:  Access  to  safe  drinking  water  and  sanitation  services  enhanced.  This 
output will improve quality of life for both urban and rural communities in Pingjiang County. This 
output includes (i) the construction of a drinking water supply plant and supply of safe drinking 
water  to  107  villages  in  14  towns;  (ii)  separation  of  rainwater  from  sewers  in  urban  and  rural 
Pingjiang  County

17. 
Output 3: Circular agriculture for sustainable livestock waste management and eco-
farming  demonstrated.  This  output  will  demonstrate  circular  agricultural  practices  in  the 
management  of  livestock  waste  and  produce  organic  fertilizer  for  eco-farming  demonstration 
farms to reduce  greenhouse gas  emissions,  enhance  soil  fertility,  and  increase crop  yield and 
sustainability.  This  output  includes  (i)  treating  livestock  waste  at  livestock  farms  prior  to  soil 
application to reduce nonpoint source pollution into waterbodies significantly; and (ii) establishing 
1,930 hectares of demonstration farms to pilot eco-farming techniques such as soil conservation, 
soil  testing  and  fertilizer  recommendations  (the  “4R”  principles17),  organic  fertilizer  application, 
integrated pest management, and other climate-resilient farming practices to promote sustainable 
agricultural development. 
 
18. 
Output  4:  Green  procurement  practices  piloted  and  environmental  education 
mainstreamed.18 This output includes (i) piloting green procurement practices under the project’s 
activities;  (ii)  developing  green  procurement  guidelines  for  selected  categories  of  goods  and 
services  to  promote,  implement,  and  monitor  green  procurement  practices  in  two  key  sectors 
(agriculture  and/or  eco-farming  and  education);  (iii)  mainstreaming  environmental  education  in 
the local educational system; (iv) improving the overall environmental literacy of Pingjiang County 
residents by engaging students’ families and local communities in environmental education and 
outreach  activities;  and  (v)  disseminating  experience  and  learnings  through  national  and 
international fora to replicate and scale-up project best practices and innovations. 
 
C. 
 
The  project  will  leverage  synergies  with  ADB’s  wider  programmatic  support  prioritizing 
19. 
investments  in  natural  capital  conservation  and  restoration  across  the  YREB  to  introduce 
innovative  features,  including  the  (i)  the  establishment  of  nature-based  solutions  to  integrate 
climate  change  adaptation  and  mitigation  measures,  such  as  ecological  embankments  along 
riparian zones, wetland park restoration for water quality and flood management, and protective 
forests,  which  generate  enhanced  environmental  benefits  compared  to  traditional  engineering 
measures; (ii) piloting of county-wide inclusive drinking water supply and sanitation facilities using 
best  practices;19 (iii)  piloting  of  county-wide  integrated  disaster  risk  management;  (iv)  circular 
utilization  of  agricultural  resources  by  linking  livestock  waste  management  and  eco-farming  to

wide environmental public awareness-raising activities for a cleaner and more sustainable future 
for Pingjiang County; and (vi) mainstreaming of climate adaptation and mitigation measures  in 
project  design  and  implementation  to  increase  the  resilience  of  flood  management  systems,

Nature-positive  approach  for  post-coronavirus  disease  pandemic  assistance. 
COVID-19  has  had  a  widespread  impact,  resulting  in  social  and  economic  disruption  and 
threatening  urban  and rural  communities,  including  Pingjiang County.  The  PCG  is preparing  a 
pandemic  recovery  and  green  stimulus  plan.  The  project  is  considered  a  priority  for  the  local 
government  as  part  of  the  post-COVID-19  pandemic  multisector  response,  in  line  with  the 
ecological road map to be embedded in the forthcoming Fourteenth Five-Year Plan.21 Increased 
access  to  improved  sanitation  is  critical  to  safeguard  human  and  environmental  health.22 By 
adopting a comprehensive and gender-sensitive approach to build climate adaptation into rural–
urban planning, the project will enhance the resilience of local livelihoods and the environment. 
This is particularly relevant to prevent the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic in highly exposed 
and  vulnerable  communities  in  rural  areas,  who  are  most  negatively  affected  by  the  physical, 
economic, and health impacts of climate change.

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Technical 

A. 
 
26. 
The  project  will  apply  innovative  and  sustainable  technologies,  strengthen  climate 
resilience,  and  demonstrate  the  importance  of  adaptation  measures  in  Pingjiang  County.  The 
project  was  prepared  by  licensed  domestic  design  institutes,  taking  into  account  transaction 
technical  assistance  (TA)  consultant  recommendations  in  accordance  with  relevant  PRC 
guidelines and regulations. The technical feasibility was confirmed to be adequate after detailed 
examination  of  the  project’s  compatibility  with  local  conditions,  including  current  and  projected 
climate  variables,  availability  of  water  sources,  proximity  to  residents,  and  available  land  for 
project facilities. Alternative technical options identified the most suitable sites for the facilities, 
and different forms of river embankments and wetlands to suit the local environment. The project 
will also finance capacity building for implementing agencies’ staff to ensure adequate skills for 
project implementation and operation and maintenance (O&M).

Sustainability 

Economic and Financial Viability 

B. 
 
27. 
The economic analysis indicates that the project is economically viable, with an overall 
economic internal rate of return of 24.3% and a net present value of CNY3,400.09 million. The 
analysis also confirms the economic viability of all subprojects, with economic internal rates of 
return ranging from 19.2% to 28.3%.25 A sensitivity analysis showed that the project is resilient to 
negative scenarios such as an increase in investment costs, revenue reduction, and increase in 
O&M costs. The eco-framing subproject under Output 3 will generate revenue and is expected to 
recover all its costs from its revenue. Financial analysis of the project indicated a financial internal 
rate of return of 15.20% for this eco-farming subproject. Its financial internal rate of return exceeds 
the weighted average cost of capital of 0.54%. The financial net present value was estimated at 
CNY1,066 million. Sensitivity analysis showed that the subproject remains financially viable under 
several potential adverse scenarios. The financial analysis confirms the financial viability of the 
revenue-generating  subproject  since  the  financial  internal  rate  of  return  is  greater  than  the 
weighted  average  cost  of  capital,  and  the  financial  net  present  value  is  positive.  The financial 
sustainability of the subprojects was assessed based on the fiscal impact of counterpart funds 
during  the  project, O&M  costs,  and  the  loan  repayment  obligation.  The analysis  confirmed  the 
project’s financial sustainability since it will have substantially limited fiscal consequences for the 
PCG.26 
 
C. 
 
28. 
Assessments were carried out in the following areas: (i) integrated planning, procurement, 
and  financial  management;  (ii)  institutional  coordination  and  capacity  development;  (iii)  water 
quality  management,  integrated  flood  risk  management,  climate  adaptation  and  mitigation 
mainstreaming, and environmental planning and monitoring; (iv) wastewater and drainage system 
design, construction, and operation; and (v) sustainable and integrated urban–rural environmental 
management  and  monitoring.  The project  will  support  the  PCG  in preparing  and implementing 
countywide  capital  investment  as  well  as  strategic  cumulative  environmental  and  social 
assessments to ensure that urban and rural growth plans are sustainable. Since this is the first 
ADB  and  KfW  investment  project  with  the  PCG,  the  project  management  office  (PMO)  will 
coordinate all key tasks with the support of the project management consultants. In addition, the 
capacity-building  activities  were  designed  to  ensure  that  state-of-the-art  information  and 
communication  technology  elements  are  harnessed  to  enhance  countywide  institutional 
coordination.  These  activities  will  provide  adequate  support  for  flood  and  disaster  risk 
management, water quality, and environmental health and safety monitoring.

Poverty and social. The project is classified as general intervention for poverty reduction. 
The poverty and social analysis was undertaken based on extensive stakeholder consultations 
and social surveys during project preparation. The project’s direct beneficiaries are the 523,333 
residents  of  239  villages  in  25  project  towns  and  subdistricts  in  Pingjiang  County,  including 
254,864 women (48.7%), and 112,517 low-income people (21.5%). The project will contribute to 
poverty reduction and social development in the project area by (i) mitigating the potential impact 
of flooding and reducing flood disaster-related losses, (ii) improving access to safe drinking water 
and  sanitation  services,  (iii)  increasing  crop  yields  and  farmers’  agricultural  incomes,                        
(iv)  enhancing  residents’  skills,  (v)  increasing  jobs  and  income-generating  opportunities,  and                 
(vi) lowering health risks through an improved environment and sanitation. It is estimated that the 
project will provide 2,884 skilled and 3,712 non-skilled jobs (including non-skilled part-time jobs) 
for residents during construction. A social development action plan, including specific actions and 
targets for the poor and low-income people, has been prepared.
